NewsLine.NewsLineText: AFGHAN-USA-AID:US official in key Afghan city near Iran border

body.p: By Mike Collett-White

HERAT, Afghanistan, Sept 23 (Reuters) - A senior U.S. Treasury official visited the strategic western Afghan city of Herat near the Iranian border on Monday as part of a trip aimed at urging donors to come up with cash they pledged to the war-torn state after the fall of the Taliban.
John Taylor, the U.S. Treasury's under-secretary for international affairs, met provincial governor Ismail Khan and visited a customs clearance centre in a brief stopover.

According to an Afghan foreign ministry spokesman in Herat, Taylor discussed the planned reconstruction of a badly damaged 600-mile (965-km) road linking Herat with the cities of Kandahar in the south and the capital Kabul in the east.

The three-year $250 million project is being funded by the United States, which will pay $80 million, and Japan and Saudi Arabia, which will each contribute $50 million. Washington will seek additional donations.
Iran is already funding a major road project linking the city of Herat to the Iranian-Afghan border.

The projects, and plans to run a $2.0-3.0 billion natural gas pipeline from resource-rich Turkmenistan through Herat and east to Pakistan, have led some commentators to speak of a new "Great Game" in Afghanistan, evoking Britain and Russia's 19th century competition for influence in the region.
After the fall of the Taliban late last year major economic projects have been proposed and countries and businesses are targeting the spoils.

Political tensions between Iran and the United States, partly sparked by Washington branding Tehran as part of an "axis of evil" threatening global security, have made Khan a key player in the battle for influence in post-Taliban Afghanistan.

In an interview with Reuters earlier on Monday the powerful local leader played down international rivalries in his province, but expressed concern that any deterioration in relations between Iran and the United States over Afghanistan could harm Herat.
AFGHAN IMPATIENCE
Taylor's visit comes amid growing frustration in Afghanistan at the lack of international aid to reconstruct badly damaged infrastructure.
Donors pledged Afghanistan $1.8 billion in aid this year, but only half has been received, according to Adib Farhadi, head of economic affairs at the Afghan foreign ministry.
Taylor met Afghan President Hamid Karzai in Kabul on Sunday, and discussed the issues of aid and the redenomination of the Afghan currency planned for later this year.
"He...voiced support for the introduction of a new Afghan currency and efforts to speed up the reconstruction with the help of donor countries," a U.S. embassy spokesman said.
U.S. Treasury Secretary Paul O'Neill called on donor states last week to honour their pledges to Afghanistan quickly.
The United States itself has promised hundreds of millions of dollars in aid, but this is dwarfed by its military budget in Afghanistan which has already run well into billions of dollars.
The foreign ministry spokesman said Khan had raised the issue of whether more aid should be channelled directly to ministries rather than through international groups like the United Nations.
"Khan expressed the concern of the Afghan people about whether there was an alternative way of giving more funds directly to the different ministries," he said.
Taylor visited a customs clearance centre in Herat which provides Khan with much of his income. While he has passed some of this on to Kabul, it may seek a bigger cut in future.
Some Western diplomats say governors in outlying regions are reluctant to surrender their income and influence to Kabul, preferring instead to preserve their fiefdoms.
Khan said he supported Karzai's government, but had decided to turn down an offer to join his cabinet as interior minister because he wanted to concentrate on rebuilding Herat province.
